. I am an officer, and searched him; he said he had only 2s., which his wife gave him that morning; I found 3s. in his pocket, and 1s. at his foot; I suppose it had dropped.
Prisoner's Defence. My wife gave me 5s. that morning - a person came in who wanted change; I had not enough by 2s., which I took out of my pocket, and afterwards paid myself out of the till.
GUILTY. Aged 29.
The prisoner received an excellent character, and was strongly recommended to mercy .
Confined Three Months .

1295.
WILLIAM FATHERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 9 shillings, and 1 sixpence , the monies of
Thomas Webster
.

GEORGE BOWERS BAKER
. I am son-in-law to Thomas Webster, a gold-beater , who lives in Porter-street, Newport-market. The prisoner was formerly in his employ. On the 18th of March I put 9s. 6d. into my desk, which I locked - it was Webster's money; I left the prisoner in the counting-house (he was not then in the employ) - next morning I found the desk wrenched open, and the money gone.

JOSHUA IVORY
. I am a beadle. I apprehended the prisoner on the 7th of April, and he said, "I have only taken a few shillings out of master's desk."
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Three Months .

1296.
WILLIAM DAVIES
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JAMES WHITE
. I am a newspaper agent . The prisoner was in my employ - he was to receive money, and pay it to me as soon as he came home. On the 28th of April he paid me no money on account of Mr. Lutz.

ROBERT WILLIAMS
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner at Greenwich, and said, "What have you done with the 2l. 5s. belonging to your master?" he said,"I know I took it - I and another boy spent it;" he was then on board the Marine Society ship; I had read him a warrant charging him with taking this money.
GUILTY Aged 13.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Nine Days .

1297.
CHARLES BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of June , 1 coat, value 50s. , the goods of
Charles McDonnell
.

CHARLES M'DONNELL. This coat hung in my hall, No. 8, Thornton-place, Regent's-park
, on Saturday the 2d of June, and while I was out I heard it was taken. I went to the office and found it there.

ANN SUTTON
. I am a servant at No. 8, Thornton-place. Mr. McDonnell lodged there. On Saturday last, the prisoner came with a letter, and told me to take it up to mistress. I went up, and when I was on the stairs I heard him come along the hall. I looked down and saw him take this coat off the pegs, he doubled it under hisarm and went out - I gave an alarm. Turner stopped him and I took the coat from him.

EDWARD TURNER
. I stopped the prisoner as he was running - Sutton had taken the coat from him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in distress and had been drinking.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

1298.
JOHN ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , 2 window sashes, value 2s., and 16 panes of glass, value 10s. , the goods of
James Sherman
.

JAMES SHERMAN. I deal in building materials . These sashes were in a house at St. Catharine's-dock
, which had been sold; they were in the parlour, separated from the house - I had employed the prisoner that day - I had bought them.

WILLIAM SIDGROVE
. On the 1st of June, in the morning. I met the prisoner in White Hart-street, Aldgate, with these sashes; he said they belonged to Mr. Beard. I said he had bought nothing at the last sale, and I would go to his house - I went there and gave him in charge.

ROBERT BURGESS
. I took him in charge.
GUILTY. Aged 21.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Two Months .
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, JUNE 2.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1299.
THOMAS THOMAS
was indicted for on the 7th of May ,
feloniously, willfully, and maliciously assaulting
Rosetta Cohen
, spinster , at St. Dunstan, Stepney, in a certain public street and highway there, with intent the garments and clothes, which she then wore, wilfully. &c. to deface against the statute the said garments, being the goods of
Hyam Benjamin Cohen
.

ROSETTA COHEN. I was twelve years old last January. On the 7th of May I was in York-street, Stepney
, and stopped to look at Punch and Judy. I saw the prisoner following me, whichever way I went. I had seen him on the Friday night before, in Whitechapel, but had no quarrel with him - I said nothing to him; I did not see him do any thing - but Smith came and took me into a hairdresser's shop, and told me to feel my pocket and see if I had lost any thing. I found my pelisse was cut as if with a knife - I lost nothing; I had a silver thimble and pencil there.
HYAM BENJAMIN COHEN. This child is my daughter, and resides with me - a gentleman called and took me to York-street; I found her in a hair-dresser's shop with her pelisse cut.

HENRY WHITFIELD
. On the 7th of May I was selling shrimps, and saw Rosetta Cohen in the street; I saw the prisoner go up to her, take a knife out of his pocket, and cut her pelisse one way - he then shut his knife, put it into his pocket, and appeared to be stooping to find her pocket-hole; he then took his knife out again and cut it the other way.

GEORGE WATSON
. I stood next to the prisoner, and saw him take the knife and cut the girl's pelisse across twice.

RICHARD SMITH
. I am a patrol. In consequence of what the witnesses told me I came up, and ask the prisoner into custody. I found no knife d

HENRY WHITFIELD
. I am sure he used of knife - it was a sort of square handled knife.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he was merely standing to look at the show; and was perfectly innocent.
GUILTY. Aged 18.

Judgment Respited
.

1300.
JAMES PINN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of April , 2 coal-hods, value 2l. 2s.; 2 tea-kettles, value 30s., and 1 tea-pot, value 9s. , the goods of
Richard Levett
.
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

RICHARD LEVETT. I am an ironmonger , and live in Broad-street, Ratcliff. On the 16th of April the prisoner called at my shop, and said he was directed by a lady in the neighbourhood to get a coal-scuttle, kettle, and teapot, and would I let her have two of each to show her, and she would return one of each in half an hour - he said"I expect you will give me a few shillings for my trouble." I knew him before; he took the goods, and never returned. I did not see him again till yesterday - I wrote down the prices by his desire - my man delivered them to him.
Prisoner's Defence. I buy goods on commission - I sold them to a person who owes me 16l. - I cannot get the money for them.
RICHARD LEVETT. I never dealt with him before.
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Confined Three Months .

1301.
WILLIAM ADAMS
and
JOHN BARRATT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence , the property of
William Perkins
.

WILLIAM PERKINS. On the 10th of April I was mending a fence by the road side, at South Mimms
- Adams came up, and asked if I had seen any beast go by that day - I said No - he said, "Well, I suppose they are not gone by yet - it is about five o'clock, is it not?" - I took out my watch, and said, "It is." Barratt then passed by, and dropped a needle-case out of his hat - Adams took it up, and asked if it was mine - I said, "No, it is that man's" - he said,"I wonder what he has got in it" - he shook it, then opened it, and there was a needle in it - he took it out, and said,"Now I'll have a little fun, and get a little beer of him" - he then called to Barratt, and said "Have you lost any thing?" he said "Not that I know of" - he then said "Yes, a needle-case;" he called him back, and gave it to him. Barratt took it, touched his hat, and said, "I am much obliged to you," and was going away - Adams said "What is in it?" - he said"A needle;" Adams said he would bet a pint of beer that there was not. Barrett said he would lay 5s. there was; they went on till they got up to a sovereign. Adams asked me to lay the sovereign - I refused, but through his persuasion I did, at last. I gave Adams my watch to hold against the sovereign - the case was opened, there was a needle and pin in it. Adams then gave him my watch - I said"It is a complete swindle, but if you will go home with me I'll give you the sovereign" - they went 40 or 50 yards. Barrett then attempted to run off - I seized him, and they both struck me violently. Barratt exclaimed with an oath,"Knock his head off." Adams struck me violently, and rather stanned me, but as soon as I could, I cried Murder! and still kept hold of Barratt; they then threatened to kill me if I did not let go. Huntley and other people then came up; and then they gave me my watch and 1s. 6d. which I had laid with the watch. I had them secured.

THOMAS HUNTLEY
. I was in the road, and heard a great noise. I went up and saw Perkins and Barratt struggling in the road. Adams kicked him several times. I ran up and said "Are you going to murder him?" they made no reply; he said they had swindled him out of his watch.

FREDERICK PROPSTRING
. I am a constable, and apprehended Barratt. I found some cups and balls, and needle cases on him.
ADAMS Defence. I gave the watch to the man as soon as he had won it - he caught hold of him and said he would have it back. Barratt called Murder! and I helped him.

BARRATT's Defence. On my way to Barnet I saw the prosecutor in conversation with this man, who is a stranger. I accidentally dropped a case, containing two needles, but did not know it; the prosecutor betted his watch, and 1s. 6d. that it did not contain two needles - it was found to contain one pin and one needle, which he must have placed there - this caused the dispute; he refused to comply, struck me violently, and injured me; after recovering, I returned his watch and money. He demanded 5s. for the insult which I gave him, and went away, but he had me apprehended.

WILLIAM PERKINS
. I did take 5s. but was so stunned with the kicks and blows, I did not know what I was about, or I would not have done it.

ADAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 38.

BARRATT -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1302.
RICHARD TAYLOR
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
William Helder
, on the King's highway, on the 2d of April , at St. Giles-in-the-Fields, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 20l.; 1 chain, value 5l.; 1 ring, value 15s., and 3 seals, value 10l. , his property.
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM HELDER. I am an attorney of Clifford's-inn. On Monday, the 2d of April, between five and six o'clock in the evening, I was going up George-street, St. Giles
, and on arriving at the corner of a street which leads to Meux's brewhouse, I received a quantity of mud in my face, eyes, and mouth, from some person, but I do not know who; it got so much in my eyes that I could not see; I was then struck in my stomach, which I drew in, and my watch was immediately taken from my fob; the blow was given by a fist I am certain; it was so sudden; and the watch was taken suddenly. The blow did not hurt me much; I felt my watch go - it was a gold one, and had a gold chain and three seals - it might be worth 40l. or 50l. together; my watch-chain hung out. I saw the person who took the watch, and followed him; it was after the mud was thrown in my eyes that he took it, and whether he came in front of me I cannot say, but I saw him, followed him, and seized him by the shoulder, and am certain that was the person who took it - he had ran about fifteen yards before I took him; he then turned, struck me a violent blow in my mouth, and disengaged himself by struggling; and left a piece of his coat in my hand; I am certain he left it in my hand - I dropped it, pursued, and caught him again, about fifteen or twenty yards further - I then struck him - we had a struggle; he struck me, and he fell from a blow of mine; I fell upon him(this was in one of the narrow streets in St. Giles', I do not know the name) - he then disengaged himself again, and ran off.

Q. How did he get away at that time? A. By struggling on the ground, and crawling on his chest; I followed him again a very little way, and then caught him by the skirt of his coat, and that came off in my hand; I dropped it, and pursued again; he ran about ten yards, and entered a house - I was about to go in, but was surrounded by an immense number of men and women, who had collected; they said if I did I should be most probably murdered, and I declined it; I am not able to say whether the prisoner is the man - I cannot form an opinion about it. I do not know what became of my watch.

WILLIAM SUTTON
. I am a cooper, in the employ of Mr. Ladd, a wine-merchant, and live opposite to where this robbery was committed; it was in George-street, a most notorious place; I was in the street, going to the permit-office; I saw the prosecutor coming up the street; there was a young woman following him, soliciting him to give her something to drink - that made me notice him; he put his hand into his right-hand pocket, and gave her a shilling - I was three or four yards off; I noticed, at the same time, that the chain and seals hung a long way down Mr. Helder's thigh; Mr. Helder then passed on, and the prisoner was waiting at the corner of a little street, called Ivy-street; immediately on Mr. Helder's coming up, the prisoner drew his watch from his fob; I saw his hand go up; Mr. Helder said, "You d-nation villian!" and immediately pursued him; he ran round the corner; I am quite sure the prisoner is the man - his face was familiar to me; he and his friends live in the same street as me; I lost sight of him for a moment, while they turned the corner; I ran up, immediately, and when I got to the corner Mr. Helder had hold of him, against the wall, endeavouring to take him into custody; the prisoner struggled with him for half a minute I suppose - they both fell on the ground, and Mr. Helder came nearly between my legs; the contention continued altogether about ten minutes; the prisoner's coat was torn almost to pieces in the contention; they came on to the end of Church-lane, and there Mr. Helder knocked him down; he got up again, and ran up the lane; Mr. Helder pursued him, and I saw no more of them at that time; I returned to my own place, because I had left my door open. I attended at Marlborough-street, nearly five weeks afterwards, and saw the prisoner; I was quite certain of his person. I had seen him walk up the street one evening, about three days after the robbery - he merely walked past.

COURT. Q. You said he lived in the street? A. Yes, with his father and mother; I do not know that they are his father and mother - I did not assist the prosecutor, because I had just recovered from a violent fit of illness - I saw no blow struck previous to taking the watch - I was then five or six yards from the prisoner, and behind Mr. Helder; the prisoner's face was towards me; a blow or push might have been given without my seeing it.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Could a blow have been struck without your seeing it? A. Not if a man had lifted his arm up high; if he had run against him with his hand in his pocket I might not have seen that; if there was a blow it must have been so (making a sort of thrust) - Mr. Helder must be the best judge whether he was struck; I did not see it. The prisoner lives with his friends - I did not give information at any office; but I did to Furzman, the officer, the day following; I both named and described the prisoner, and saw him at the office five weeks after - I may have seen him twice in that interval - Mr. Helder appeared perfectly sober; I was pretty near him, but saw no blow. The prisoner was not an instant in his presence before he took the watch; he was waiting at the corner of the street - all the fighting and struggling I saw was afterwards - I solemnly swear the prisoner is the man, although his life depends on it.
JURY. Q. Did you see any mud thrown? A. I did not, nor do I think there was any thrown - I did not observe any mud, my attention was so much taken with to the contension.

MR. ADOLPHUS to MR. HELDER. Q. This was at six o'clock in the evening? A. A little before six. I was going to my sister's in Bedford-square, and going the nearest way; I had dined at two o'clock; the mud, the blow, and the taking of the watch came all in a moment; it was not a raised blow; he struck me in the belly. I think the blow must have been given with one hand, and the watch taken with the other; the same person did both certainly.
MR. ALLEY. Q. Are you quite certain the blow was given before the watch was taken? A. Yes.
JURY. Q. What sort of a day was it? A. A lowery day; it had rained in the morning and the evening before - it was dirty there.

SAMUEL FURZMAN
. I am an officer. Sutton gave me information; he described the prisoner, and mentioned his name; I knew the prisoner before perfectly well; I searched for him both in and out of town, and apprehended him on the 2d of May, and took him to the office.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 26.

1303.
CLIFFORD ELISHA
was indicted for
embezzlement .
MESSRS. BRODERICK and PRENDERGAST conducted the prosecution.

JOHN AUSTIN
. I am one of the
trustees of the poor of St. Leonard, Shoreditch
, and have been so about twenty-seven years - there are sixty or seventy trustees - the prisoner was the parish-clerk , and he received the burial dues, and money for tombs and vaults; he had a salary of 12l. a-year; he was appointed by the Board of Trustees; I have been a trustee from that time to this; I have received money from him for tombs and vaults, when I was church warden; he accounted very justly to me; his duty was to account for what he received once a month.

Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. Was he parish-clerk before the passing of the Act? A. No, after. Mr. Plimley, the vicar, appoints the parish-clerk. Nine trustees form a board - they have appointed a clerk for themselves, that is John Scarr; the prisoner was parish-clerk, but had 12l. a-year for receiving these fees. The church-wardens rendered their accounts when they were called upon, and their accounts are audited by the trustees at their audit committee; there is but one general audit in the year, that is about June; the account is sworn to, and signed by the trustees present; that account should include fees received by the clerk for the burial-ground. There was a struggle between the vicar and the parish about who was to appoint the parish-clerk; it ended in a law-suit giving the vicar the right; the prisoner has had the place ever since. I have not heard of a desire lately to appoint somebody else.
Q. Were you the bearer of a letter from the prisoner to the Board of Trustees after he was accused of dishonesty? A. Yes. I gave it to the chairman.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. The contest was about the parish-clerk? A. Yes - a man named Limming then received the parish fees, and then the prisoner did it. The Vicar always expected the clerk to receive the parish fees. I believe the prisoner attended with his books and vouchers in June, when the churchwardens' accounts were audited. I do not know whether he accounted on oath - the churchwarden did. The prisoner accounted to me once a month, when I was churchwarden - he rendered no other account.

COURT. Q. Did he account every month for the receipt of burial fees? A. Yes, and for vaults and tombs - that was his duty, and he did so with me. I was churchwarden in 1819 and 1820. I was a trustee in August 1825.

SAMUEL BLACKBURN
. I am a trustee of Shoreditch parish, under the Act of Parliament, and was so the beginning of this year. I was appointed one of the committee to investigate the churchwardens' accounts for the last four years. We had a number of meetings - the business was exceedingly complicated, and took a great deal of time; we began the last week in December, or first in January. Mr. Lane's accounts were investigated - he had been churchwarden, and left off a few weeks after Easter, 1826 - he was churchwarden in 1825. A very long report was made from the committee to the Board, and it was resolved that the prisoner should be prosecuted. I knew nothing of any charge against him before; the investigation was gone into without any idea of a felonious charge. After various applications made to the prisoner, at length these books (looking at them) were produced, under an order from the churchwardens, other applications having failed; here is one containing an account from 1823, to June 1826, it professes to be an account of monies received on account of the churchwardens for graves, vaults, and burials - it contains an account of money received in August, 1825. I have examined it throughout - no credit is given for money received from Mr. Brown, for a grave - there is no account of money received for a grave for Miss Storey - if he received any sum for it, it ought to have appeared here.
Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. I am at the head of a large establishment.

Q. Are you not a teacher of a congregation? A. I am, of the independent denomination. I was elected trustee seven or eight years ago - I attended pretty regularly. I generally saw Mr. Westall there - I cannot say whether he is more active than myself. I never heard him called the King of the parish. I have no wish about who shall.be parish clerk. I never said I would do all I could to get the prisoner moved out - it is very probable I may have said in conversation with the inquiries of the committee, that such a man ought to be turned out. I am ready to admit that; I have no recollection of saying I would do all I could to get him turned out - I never said so.

Q. Did you not say "I should he glad to hear he had run away and fixed his bail?" A. I never did. I said it was more than probable that he would, having done so on a former occasion. I believe the Grand Jury threw out two bills.

Q. On your solemn oath, did you not say, "It matters not; I will have another bill, or I have not done with him yet?" A. I met Mr. Westall, the church warden, on his return from the Grand Jury. I used no such words to him, nor to Mr. Teal - I have frequently talked with Mr. Teal on the subject. I believe I was one of the first who went before the Magistrate - several of us went; I believe Mr. Searr attended as solicitor. Mr. Harmer was applied to - but, I believe, I and the other trustees thought he had neglected us - we attended on the Magistrate three or four times - there was an application to discharge the warrant when the bill was thrown out, we opposed that - Mr. Harmer attended us; we understood that certain links of evidence had not been gone into; and we merely stated, that the case on which the warrant was granted, had not been brough! before the Grand Jury. I think only one charge was investigated by the Magistrate - several were made. The board ordered hand-bills to be printed to cause the prisoner to be apprehended - I believe I gave the order to the printer, he was taken three or four weeks after. I did not send three or four paupers to take him - he was taken by some paupers.

Q. Can any human being, by looking at this book, tell whether the money paid by Brown, for Miss Storey's grave was paid in or not? A. We looked through all the bills which the church warden rendered - no such entry appears either in the book or the bills, this book was obtained by a particular application from the Vicar. The prisoner afterwards applied for the book, to go over it, and give explanations. I believe his application was denied - I do not recollect having any conversation with Mr. Lane; something was said about a vindictive feeling, and I said if a fine of 1s. would answer the ends of justice, I should be satisfied.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Were the monthly accounts produced by the prisoner? A. No; by the churchwarden; I saw them - they were in the prisoner's hand-writing; there is no account in any of them for Miss Storey's grave - here are the accounts delivered at the time Mr. Lane was churchwarden, there is no such entry. I believe they are in the prisoner's hand-writing - the names are in ink, but in many instances the figures are in pencil, I only went before the Grand Jury on this bill; when Mr. Westall said the bill was thrown out, I said "The board will not allow the business to rest here - there are too many charges; other bills will be preferred.

COURT. Q. Is this the same charge as the other hills related to? A. No; we could not swear to particular pieces of money in the other cases - what I said about a fine of 1s., was merely to shew that no vindictive feeling actuated us.

PHILIP BROWN
. I am an undertaker. I paid a sum to the prisoner's wife for a grave for Miss Storey, on the 25th of August, 1825; I paid a sum of 5l. 5s. - I gave her five sovereigns - I got a receipt a fortnight or three weeks after - I do not know whose hand-writing it is.
Cross-examined. Q. State, as well as you can, what portion you paid in sovereigns? A. It was in five sovereigns; I paid it to Mrs. Elisha at his house.

SAMUEL BLACKBURN
. This receipt is in the prisoner's hand-writing. (Receipt read.)

THOMAS LANE
. In 1825 I was a churchwarden. I allowed the prisoner 12l. that year for receiving the dues - he rendered me an account of them; but not regularly, every month - there was sometimes a delay; when they were delivered, they were called over with this book - there is no account of a grave for Miss Storey - it should he there, I presume; but previous to my being in office they were not so regularly kept. I received the sums, entered here, at various times, but not always when the book was given in - he balanced his account at the close of the year; there is no sum of five guineas entered.

Cross-examined. Q. Though there is no specific entry, can you take upon yourself to swear that neither him nor his wife ever accounted to you for it? A. I cannot tell what he might have paid it from (looking at a receipt for 35l.) - I do not know whose writing this is - here is written, on the back, ten guineas and five guineas. I would not swear this five guineas has never been paid.
The Court ruled that there was no proof of the money coming to the hands of the prisoner, in the particular specie charged.
NOT GUILTY .

1304.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , three 50l. and two 20l. Bank notes, the property of
William Jones
from his person .

WILLIAM JONES. I am a weigher at the Custom-house - I have known the prisoner some years; he belonged to the Two penny Post-office , in Gerrard-street. On the 28th of March I received 355l. 16s. 2d. at the Bank, by an order from the Court of Chancery, a suit having been decided in my favour - the prisoner went with me to receive it - I got five 50l., five 20l., five 5l. notes, and 16s. 2d.; it was between eleven and one o'clock, and the prisoner received 77l. on the same suit - his brother and brother's wife, his sister's husband, Mr. Gregory, and his clerk, were with us; I put the notes into my trousers pocket, all in a lump together. I went to Mr. Hill, my lawyer, in Welbeck-street, and paid him two 20l. notes, and he gave me 5l. in change. I walked a little way; we then all got into a coach, I think the prisoner was on the box - he waited at a public-house while I went in to Mr. Hill's - I then went there to him, and was intoxicated - I did not come to my senses till next morning, when I was at my own house, in Draper's-buildings, London-wall - I missed three 50l., and one 20l. note; the others were still in my pocket, but rather open, not wrapped up as I had put them in - I went to the prisoner's house at Paddington, in two or three days, with an officer twice, but could not find him.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. There was alarge party of you? A. Yes; after receiving the money we went and dined at a public-house, opposite the Mansion-house - I took out a 20l. note there, and paid Bell 18l., and I lent Mr. Heck a 20l. note; I was intoxicated; I remember coming out and saying, "Oh! come, I am trumps - I have lent him the money" - I lent no other money - I have found out Heck's lodging, and they tell me he has not been at home for some weeks.

ROBERT BELL
. I am clerk to Mr. Gregory, the solicitor - I went with them to the Bank, and saw the money paid, and from the state the prosecutor was in, I was afraid he might be robbed, and desired the cashier to give him five 50l. notes, as they could be better traced - he put his money into his trouser's pockets - we went into the Mansion-house public-house - Mr. Gregory wished us to stay by him, as he owed him 18l. - we had 3lbs. of beef-steaks and some porter - he put a 20l. note on the table, and I desired the persons there to mind that it was a 20l. - the prisoner was one of the company - I took the note (Heck then called him out) - I think he put his notes back into his pocket - we took a coach in Cheapside, and I went with him to Welbeck-street (the prisoner was on the box) - I saw him take out the notes, which were wrapped up closely - he there paid two 20l. notes - I then went with him to another public-house, staid a few minutes, and then left them, exactly at five o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. When Heck called him out, did you go with him? A. No; when he came in he said he was trumps, and had lent the money - I have heard that Heck is absent - the prisoner is a letter-sorter.
- GREGORY. I am an ironmonger. I was with Bell - his account is correct - I left them at the Mansion-house public-house.

WILLIAM MOORE
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Oxford-street. On the 29th of March, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, the prisoner came to the shop with two men and two women, who said they wanted some boots and shoes, and could I give them change for a 50l. note, or they must go into the City - I fitted them all but one man; a young man who came with the prisoner paid me a 50l. note - I asked for the name and address - the prisoner himself wrote in it, "Jones, Bank of England, Prade-street, Paddington," and I wrote "March 29, W. M." I gave the change to the young man.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see a foreigner there? A. Yes; he came in after the note was produced, I think - when I asked for the address, one of the women said to the prisoner, "Put your name and address."

HENRY SELWOOD
. I am clerk to Mr. Hill. The prisoner paid me two 20l. notes - I gave him 5l.; he had other notes in his hand; they were new notes.

JAMES LANGRIDGE
. I am shopman to Mr. Blackman, a linen-draper, of Judd-street; the prisoner came to my shop with two women, the latter end of March, or beginning of April; they bought 2l. or 3l. worth of goods, and he gave me a 20l. note, which I gave Mr. Blackman, who gave him change - I did not ask the prisoner for his address, but he gave it to master, as "Bishop Cromer-street" - I did not see master write the note.

- BLACKMAN. I remember some persons coming to my shop - I cannot say the prisoner was one - I received the note, and paid it away to Messrs. Leaf and Severs, Old Change; he mentioned the name of Bishop - I put my initials on it, when I paid it away.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you swear to that note? A. Yes - because I had no other at that time; I paid it away eight or nine days after - I had no other 20l.; I only know I paid them the same note; I sent it by my man; I have not been to see if Bishop lives in Cromer-street.

GEORGE DYER
. I am a clerk in the Bank - I produce a 50l. note, and a 20l. note; the 50l. has "Jones, Praed-street, Paddington," on it.
MR. BLACKMAN. This is the 20l. note, and has my initials - I had no other.

MARY MOSS
. I am house-keeper to the prosecutor. On the 28th of March, about half-past nine o'clock, he was brought home in a coach, by five people, very drunk; they left him at the corner of the buildings, and fetched me to get him home; the prisoner was one of them - also Heck and his wife; they staid till a quarter-past ten o'clock, and next morning he complained of being robbed.

JAMES BOQUET
. I am a clerk at the Bank. I paid this money to Jones, but the clerk who entered the notes, is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1305.
WILLIAM CONDELL
was indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
George Dobree
, about the hour of ten in the night of the 1st of March , at St. Pancras, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 6 coats, value 10l.; 525 yards of silk, value 59l.; 4 pairs of trousers, value 50s.; 5 handkerchiefs, value 6s.; 21 yards of cambric, value 5l.; 8 shawls, value 59l.; 3 scarfs, value 12l.; 1 veil, value 10l., and 1 pelisse, value 20s. , his property.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY -
DEATH .

1306.
WILLIAM CONDELL
,
GEORGE PLUMMER
, and
ELIZABETH (THE WIFE OF THOMAS) HARMAN
were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Samuel James Wood
, about the hour of twelve, in the night of the 2d of April , at St. James, Clerkenwell, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 4 coats, value 4l. 10s.; 2 waistcoats, value 10s.; 6 pairs of trousers, value 5l.; 2 necklaces, value 7s.; 2 bracelets, value 1s.; 2500 yards of lace, value 81l.; 20 caps, value 40s.; 14 veils, value 7l.; 2 umbrellas, value 12s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 9 lace collars, value 40s., and 36 cap-crowns, value 40s. , his property.

CONDELL
pleaded GUILTY -
DEATH .
MR. ANDREWS and MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

SAMUEL JAMES WOOD. I am a pawnbroker , and live at No. 35, St. John-street, in the parish of St. James, Clerkenwell
, and rent the house. I keep my pledges in the top room of my house. On Tuesday, the 3d of April, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning, I discovered that it had been broken open; the thieves had taken a square of glass out of the sash of the top-room window, and opened the sash; two iron bars were then taken off and a padlock, which fastened them, was wrenched off; they could get along the gutter from an empty house next door; one shelf of lace was completely emptied - I missed the articles stated in the indictment, among others; they were worth more than 100l. - I had examinedthe padlock the day previous, or the day before that, it was safe.

Cross-examined by MR. DOWLING. Q. Have you any partner? A. No; it was quite daylight when I discovered it; I had been in the room on the Monday afternoon, and saw every thing safe; the bars were fastened inside - they opened the sash, and broke the bars, I think.

MARY ANN VANDEVELDE
. In April last I lived with the prisoner Plummer, in Pettiford-court, Drury-court, Strand - the prisoner Harman lived with Condell, in Grange-court, Clare-market. On Monday night, the 2d of April, I was at Condell's, in Grange-court, with Plummer - Condell and Harman were there; I heard Condell ask Plummer to go with him to Mr. Wood's; I had heard it mentioned two or three nights before; Condell said they could go and get money at Mr. Wood's, and would Plummer go with him, and it was agreed that we should meet on that Monday night. On Monday night Condell asked Plummer to go with him - he said they were to open the door of an empty house next door, and get in from the roof of the house; I went with them - Condell did not say I was to go.

Q. Did not Condell and Plummer go out on Sunday night? A, Yes; they came back, and said they had been to Mr. Wood's, but could not do it, as there were women about. On Monday we went and had tea at Condell's, when he asked Plummer to go; he said he did not mind; I and Harman went with them; we set out about eight o'clock or a little after - we went on to Thompson's, in Holborn, and there had some gin; Harman said she should like to go with them - Condell said he did not mind, and it was agreed we should all go together; we went straight to Mr. Wood's- I think it had struck nine when we got there; it was dark - I did not know the house; Condell pointed out the empty house, but did not go in then; we went and had some beer at a corner public-house, and staid there till about ten o'clock; we then came out, and walked up and down. - Condell said, "It is too soon yet;" we all four walked about till near twelve o'clock; Condell then opened the door of the empty house, with a crow-bar; there was no one about at that time; a coach was going by, which prevented the noise being heard - the door opened a little way, and they put in pieces of wood; Condell and Plummer went into the house - Harman and I staid outside - it was agreed before that we should not go in. The door was fastened after they went in - Harman tried it; we two then went straight home. We left our place again about four o'clock, and got there about five; they had not desired us to come back; we went of our own accord; it was them just daylight. We went up to the empty house; there was a coach going by at the time - Harman coughed, as a signal for them to come out, and they came out with two bundles; they said they contained lace; we passed over to St. John's-square; Plummer gave me one bundle, and Condell gave Harman the other; we took them to Condell's lodging; Harman said, when any one came by, "We had better make haste, or we shall be too late for the coach." We got to Condell's near upon six o'clock; Condell opened the bundles there - there was a great deal of lace, caps, and veils; there were three coats; Condell had one of the coats on when he came out of the house, and a pair of trousers on; there were three pairs of trousers; Plummer also had a pair of trousers on; there was some necklaces and bracelets; Harman gave me some of them - they opened them all, and put them into a box in the room; there was some lace, veils, and caps, tied in a yellow handkerchief; there was also two umbrellas; I went out, and pawned a pair of trousers, and Harman went and pawned a coat at Cameron's; I went into the shop, and Harman into the box; Condell asked me to pawn them - we went straight home to Condell's lodging. The officers came there as soon as we had done our breakfast; they handcuffed us three together, but Plummer was not there; he had gone out about two minutes before they came; Avis broke the box open, and Clements found the bundle. A man named Williams came there, and had some tea and gin.

Cross-examined. Q. How old are you? A. Nineteen last Saturday; I have come from the House of Correction; I have been there nine weeks; I am an unfortunate girl; I first told this story on Easter Saturday - I had then been in custody a week and a few days; I was the first to communicate it; the officers did not ask me to do it; I have no annuity, or any thing but what my mother sends me - she has 2l. a month for me, but keeps it till I am of age - Mr. Oliver pays it. I have come here to save myself, not to save my annuity; I know I should lose it if I was convicted. - Plummer is nineteen years old to-day.
MR. ANDREWS. Q. How long had you known Plummer? A. I had lived with him for twelve months.
COURT. Q. How long after they went into the house did you remain there? A. Five or ten minutes; we then went home, and when we went in the morning we waited about ten minutes before they came out.
MR. WOOD. I think it must have taken them an hour to break into the house.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer of Marlborough-street. On Tuesday morning, the 3d of April, about half-past eight o'clock, I and Clements went to Condell's lodging, in Grange-court, into the front parlour, on the right-hand; we found Condell, Harman, and Vandevelde there; I went up to Condell, said I wanted him, and handcuffed him; Clements took the others; I found a number of articles in this box (producing it) - I found a crow-bar, a picklock, a centre-bit, and punches - they are such tools as house-breakers use; it is not a complete set; I have had the property ever since. Condell said the box belonged to him; I asked him for the key - he said he had lost it, and that the box had been brought that morning, by two men, named Welch and Smith (Vandevelde was there); I asked Condell if he knew where they lived - he said No; he said the implements were brought in by the same men; I then got Mrs. Westcoat to search the women; she gave me a duplicate, which she said she took from Vandevelde - also a pair of bracelets, and in amber necklace; Vandevelde said Harman had given them to her - Condell was present. I also found in a cupboard in the room, some duplicates of lace, and different things.
Cross-examined. Q. They were all in Condell's lodging? A. Yes. A pair of blue trousers were found on Plummer.

THOMAS CLEMENTS
. I am an officer, and went with Avis. Condell and the two women were there; I found these two umbrellas, and a bundle in a yellow handkerchief, containing ten black veils, seven white veils, fourteen collars, seven yards of lace, and fifteen pieces of lace; Mrs. Westcoat found in Harman's pocket a cap and twelve cap-crowns; I found some cruets in a cupboard.

MARY WESTOOAT
. My husband is an officer. I searched Harman, and found in her bosom a lace cap, which I gave to Clements - she said she put it there to get some gin. I found the bracelets and necklace in Vandevelde's bosom, and a duplicate in her shoe.

JOSIAH SHERGOLD
. I was with the offiers. I saw the property found. I produce three coats, two pairs of trousers, and thirty-seven duplicates, which I found at Condell's- I saw Avis find the tools. On Saturday I went to Gibralta-row, Prospect-place, Tothill-fields, to see Sarah Horsford, and while there Plummer came in; he had been in the house, and been down the yard, and as he came back Horsford said, "Oh, my God! there is George;" Plummer was then within hearing; I took him, and found on him a gold pin, a silver pencil-case, and a knife - Mr. Wood claims part of them; I asked Plummer his name - he said Wilmott, and asked what I wanted him for; I told him he was accused of robbing Mr. Balfour, Mr. Wood, and Mr. Dobree - he said he knew nothing of it.

SAMUEL SALT
. I am a watchman, and went with Avis to Condell's, and assisted in searching the room - I found fifty-one duplicates belonging to Mr. Wood - I afterwards went with Shergold to Plummer's, in Pettiford-court, and there found some picklock-keys, a phosphorus-box, a turn-screw, a centre-bit (such as housebreakers use), and forty-four duplicates.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know it was Plummer's lodging, except from what the landlady said? A. No; it is No. 2.
M. A. VANDEVELDE. I lived at No. 2, in that court with him.

MARY ANN BUCKLER
. I live in Rosamond-street, Clerkenwell. I pawned this veil at Mr. Wood's on the 19th of March, for 5s. - I went for it again, and could not have it - I am certain this is it - I have the duplicate of it.
Cross-examined. Q. What do you know it by? A. The pattern - I did the hem of it myself, and know my work.
Mr. WOOD. I know this umbrella very well, and have no doubt of this lace - I keep a duplicate on the goods. These duplicates, found at Condell's, were in my house on the Monday night.

JOSEPH HENDERSON
. I lived in Kennington-lane. I pawned these nine pieces of lace at Wood's, in June last.(These were part of the goods found at Condell's).

JOHN COX
. I pawned some lace at Mr. Wood's; some of this I believe to be mine; it is the same pattern, but it being off the cards, I cannot swear to it.

HENRY POWELL
. I am a shopman to Mr. Cameron, of the Strand. Vandevelde pawned these trousers with me, and Harman pawned this coat at the same time - I gave this duplicate to Harman.

WILLIAM STEVENS
. I am a shopman to Mr. Cameron. I took the trousers from Vandevelde, and gave her this duplicate.
GEORGE AVIS. I found this pair of trousers on Plummer.
MR. WOOD. I believe these trousers to be mine. I had several pairs of them - I cannot swear to them - no one article is worth 40s.
M. A. VANDEVELDE. Plummer told me, when he came home, that he had got a pair of Mr. Wood's trousers on.

PLUMMER's Defence. My Lord, I should wish respectfully to submit a few words, in pollution of the offence I am charged with. I have laboured hard through life, but I have had the misfortune to become acquainted with this wretched character, who is trying to swear away my life - I have kept her by my industry, little knowing her extravagant ways - she has had acquaintances at my lodgings, which I was utterly ignorant of. She has had a brother found guilty at this bar; another brother, a reputed thief, and herself, a common prostitute, I trust you will consider these things, and that she has been prompted to attempt to prove this to work my destruction.
Two witnesses gave Plummer a very good character.

PLUMMER -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 19.

HARMAN -
NOT GUILTY .

1307.
WM. CONDELL
was again indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Alexander Balfour
, about the hour of ten in the night of the 21st of July
, at St. Paul, Covent Garden, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 11 pairs of trousers, value 4l.; 3 waistcoats, value 10s.; 33 yards of cloth, value 16l.; 40 yards of kerseymere, value 5l.; 1 pair of breeches, value 10s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 3s.; 1 shawl, value 5s.; 1 pair of spectacles, value 6s.; 18 yards of silk, value 2l.; 4 yards of satin, value 6s., and 1/2 a yard of cambric, value 3s. , his property; and
ELIZABETH HARMAN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the same day, and at the same parish, the same goods, knowing them to have been feloniously and burglariously stolen .*
*Plummer was included in this indictment, but not tried.

CONDELL
pleaded GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 38.
MESSRS. ANDREWS and ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM ALEXANDER BALFOUR. I am a pawnbroker , and live in Chandos-street, in the parish of St. Paul, Covent-garden
. On the night of the 21st of January, my house was broken open. I went all over the warehouse the evening before, at seven o'clock, and at eight the next morning, I was told by one of my boys that the house was broken open; the persons had broken through a trap door which led to a loft, and from thence to my warehouse; they could not break the warehouse door, but broke through the ceiling; there was an empty house adjoining, and a pair of trousers, and one or two duplicates were found in that house. I lost a number of articles, worth 60l. or 70l.

MARY ANN VANDEVELD
. About three nights before Mr. Balfour was robbed I heard a talk about it. I and Harman staid at Condell's lodgings while Condell and Plummer went to Mr. Balfour's - it was one Sunday evening, about eight o'clock at night - they returned about six in the morning, and said they got into the empty house, and got in at the roof of the house; they had taken a dark-lantern with them, also two crow-bars and some pieces of wood; they brought back some cloth, and some silk, a shawl, some breeches, waistcoats and cambric. Condell gave me some cambric, which I pawned at Mr. Cameron's, for 3s. (two or three weeks after - I have lost the duplicate - Harman was there at the time.

HENRY POWELL
. I live with Mr. Cameron a pawnbroker. I produce some cambric pawned by Vandeveld, on the 7th of February - I knew her before.

SAMUEL TAUNTON
. I am inspector of the patrol. I went to Mr. Balfour's house on the 22d of January, andfound it had been entered by some persons who came over the parepet of the adjoining empty house, and in that house I found a pair of trousers, a jacket and hat - Mr. Balfour did not claim them.
MARY ANN VANDEVELD. I do no not know these clothes.

ANN BRYANT
. My husband is a tailor. I know this shawl to be mine; I pawned it at Mr. Balfour's.

ELIZABETH LUKIN
. This handkerchief is mine, it was wrapped round some cotton, which I pawned at Mr. Balfour's.
MARY ANN VANDEVELD. I know this shawl and handkerchief were part of the things they brought away.

GEORGE AVIS
. I found this handkerchief at Harman's lodging - she said it was her's.

HARMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1308.
HENRY GODFREY
,
ABRAHAM BANKS
, and
JAMES SMITH
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of May . 20 bushels of oats, value 6l. 15s.; 4 bushels of beans, value 25s., and 1 sacks, value 12s. , the goods of
Joshua Horlock
.

JOSHUA HORLOCK. I reside at Finchley
. On the 19th of May Matthews gave me information - I went to my loft about four o'clock, and missed one sack of beans, and five of oats.

WILLIAM MATTHEWS
. I am in Mr. Horlock's employ. and took care of his horses. On Friday, the 18th of May, about seven o'clock in the evening, I saw five sacks of oats, and one of beans in the loft - I locked the loft and took away the key, and next morning, at a quarter-past five, I went there, and they were all gone; I knew the prisoners by sight - I believe they are labouring men - the lock was not forced - they had got over the chaise-house door, and could then enter the loft - I had not seen them about the premises.

ROBERT SWAN
. I am hostler at the Swan at Finchley. On Saturday, the 19th of May, about two o'clock in the morning, I saw Godfrey and another man run down a lane by our house, and fetch up a cart belonging to James Smith; they ran over the common with it, towards London; Mr. Horlock's house is between there and London; at half-past two o'clock I was going to bed, and saw them come back; I opened the window and looked out; I saw Banks, Godfrey, and another, whom I did not know; the cart was then full of something brown; they were then going towards Barnet; one of them told me to put my bl - y head in and shut the window down; Wells called a few days after; I did not see the cart brought back.

JOHN WELLS
. I drive the Boston van. On Saturday morning, the 19th of May, about ten minutes past two o'clock, I was driving through Whestone-gate, and met a cart by the eighth mile-stone, with one man at the shafts, and two pushing behind; I did not observe their persons - there was something brown in the cart.

CHARLES WOODWARD
. I live at Thomas Attfield's, and drive the Leeds waggon - I went through Barnet at twenty minutes to four o'clock on the morning of the 19th of May - when I got to Prickler's-hill I saw a cart coming behind me, and four men pushing it; they overtook me; the cart was then empty - Godfrey and Smith were pushing it - I said, "It seems heavier than a wheelbarrow;" Godfrey said it did. a bl - y sight; they were coming towards London; the other two men had passed me just before; Banks was one of them; I asked the man who was with him, where he had been; he said he had been unloading a load at the bottom of the hill, and he had another to unload.

JAMES MATTHEWS
. I am a constable of Finchley. The prosecutor gave me information, on the 19th of May - I went to his premises, and traced footsteps across the fields into the road - I saw some oats spilt near the gate, and traced a narrow-wheeled cart from near the edge - I went and looked at Joseph Smith's cart, which has narrow wheels, and in the cart was a few oats - I apprehended the prisoners - Smith said, "You take me, and don't say for what;" Banks said, "You dragged the man's cart, without a horse, with his oats in it;" Banks said, as they were going to prison, "If they had wrote it down for Swan he could not have spoke otherwise than he did."

JOSEPH SMITH
. I live near Whetstone, and have a narrow-wheeled cart, which I keep down the lane, near the Swan public-house - I heard of this robbery on Saturday - I found my cart in its right place, about half-past seven o'clock, and twenty or thirty oats in it - I at times have oats in it.
MR. HORLOCK. My house is eight miles from London, and about three quarters of a mile on this side the Swan.
NOT GUILTY .

1309.
GEORGE FAGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 2 coach wheels, value 35s. , the goods of
Samuel Hobson
and others.

JOHN BEACH
. I am a wheelwright, in Mr. Samuel Hobson's employ - he has other partners, the premises are in Long-acre
. I missed two coach wheels, which I afterwards saw on Fisher's cart; the prisoner was frequently about our premises, he was employed by Mr. Davy, to whom one of the wheels belonged. I know these two wheels - the fellow of one is at the factory now.

JOHN LENSEY
. The prisoner sold me these two wheels on the 18th of May; he said he bought them of a gentleman's coachman - I took them home, Fisher bought them of me.

JAMES FISHER
. I bought two wheels of Lensey - Beach has claimed them since.(Property produced and sworn to.)

SAMUEL FURZMAN
. Mr. Davy brought the prisoner to the watch-house - he said he bought the wheels, and had had them some time.
GUILTY. Aged 35.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

1310.
GEORGE MAYHEW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of May , 1 cap, value 7s., and 2 pieces of leather, value 10s. , the goods of
John Burrows
, his master.

ROBERT BURROWS
. I am the brother of John Burrows, a boot-maker of Bond-street. The prisoner was in his employ; these articles were missed on the 17th of May, from a box in the parlour.(Property produced and sworn to.)

BENJAMIN WM. VALENTINE
. I am an officer. I went to the prisoner's room, and found this property; he said theleather was his own, and that his wife had brought the cap home.
Prisoner's Defence. I did a little work on my own account. I only earned 10s. a week with him. I have had the leather three years, and can produce a pair of my children's boots made from the leather.
B. W. VALENTINE. He said he had bought the leather some time ago.
ROBERT BURROWS. Our private mark is on it.
GUILTY. Aged 36.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

1311.
SAMUEL ASHTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 2 books, value 3s. , the goods of
John Chidley
.

JOHN CHIDLEY, I am a bookseller , and live in Goswell-street. On the 11th of April, between one and two o'clock, I was in the parlour, I heard a footstep, and saw the prisoner going out of the shop; I went and overtook him, putting these two books into his bosom.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY Aged 38.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Weeks .

1312.
HANNAH BARBER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 1 watch, value 3l., and 2 keys, value 1l., the goods of
William Thompson
, from his person .

WILLIAM THOMPSON. I am a seaman , and have been on shore about a fortnight. On the 29th of May, about eleven o'clock at night, I met the prisoner in Ratcliff-highway. She asked me home - I went into a house with her. I took out my watch and put it into my pocket. I went to bed with her; in about three minutes, a person came to the door, she called out to that person, then jumped out of bed and ran down-stairs as fast as she could - there was no light - I had not pulled off my clothes; the watch was in my pocket. I got up and missed it - went down and called the watchman. I have not found it; there was a light when I went there, but she put it out before we went to bed.

JOHN FOLKER
. I am a watchman. I saw Thompson, about eleven o'clock at night; he said he had been robbed, and shewed me the house - I found nobody at home, but a candle was burning; he described the girl, and gave me his address - I found the prisoner and took her to him; she has lived in that house about two months - Thompson was perfectly sober.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1313.
WALTER CREAK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , 5 shillings, and 4 sixpences, the monies of
Elizabeth Reid
, his mistress .

ELIZABETH REID. I am a baker . The prisoner was in my employ. On Sunday night Green marked some money for me, and put it into the till, by my desire - the prisoner had no business at the till; on Monday morning five marked shillings and four sixpences were found on him by the officer - I had locked the till.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How long has he lived with you? A. Twelve months; his character was good; he had 10s. a week and his board.

CHARLES GREEN
. I marked 15s. by Reid's desire; the next morning I went to the officer, and had the prisoner taken; this silver is what I marked.

WILLIAM CLARKE
. I am an officer. I was fetched, and found this money on the prisoner, with a key which opens the till.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1314.
WILLIAM PAFFEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April , 1 jacket, value 18s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 12s , the goods of
Thomas Sharp
.

EDWARD GINGER
. I am servant to Thomas Sharp. I was informed the prisoner had stolen a jacket and trousers - I ran out, and caught him with them; he fell down with them on his arms.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was crossing Whitechapel; these things laid under the shop-window - I picked them up; a man said Stop thief! I stopped directly.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

1315.
JAMES BARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of April , 1 cake of tallow greaves, value 4s. , the goods of
John King
.

JOHN KING. I am a tallow-chandler . and live at Islington
; a person told me this cake of greaves was stolen from the door; the prisoner was brought back with it.

JOHN GIRDLER
. I saw the prisoner and two other bigger lads - I turned my head and saw the other two lads placing the greaves on the prisoner's head; they told him to make haste - I stopped him with it - I heard them say, "You bl - dy fool, take it on your head. and go down Compton-street, and we will meet you there."
Prisoner's Defence. A boy said he would give me a penny, to carry it to Compton-street.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped and Discharged.
SEVENTH DAY. THURSDAY, JUNE 7.
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1316.
JAMES LOWE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , 1 goose, value 5s. , the goods of
Joseph Mazoyer
.

JOSEPH MAZOYER. I am a poulterer , and live in St. Giles'. On the 4th of June I was in my parlour, and saw the prisoner snatch a goose from the board - I followed. and took him about fifty yards off, with it.

WILLIAM KEAN
. I received him in charge; he said Copley, who had got away, took one goose, and told him to take this one.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

1317.
JOHN ASKIN
and
THOMAS SKINNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 copper, value 10s., the goods of
Robert Hardy
, and fixed to his dwelling-house .

ROBERT HARDY. I live in Glasshouse-street, Whitechapel
; my copper was fixed safe at ten o'clock at night,on the 31st of May, and next morning it was gone, when I got up; here it is - I am certain of it - I have compared it with the place it came from.

THOMAS GLOVER
. I live at the Crown public-house, Glasshouse-street. I got up about five o'clock in the morning, and saw the prisoners walking up and down the street; I saw Skinner get over the gates of Hardy's-yard - Askin walked to and from till he found an opportunity; Skinner then lifted the copper over the pails, and Askin's received it from him - I got two men to assist, and took them both - Hardy claimed it.

THOMAS JUDD
. I secured them immediately.
ASKIN's Defence. I was coming from the Docks - a man said, "Lay hold of this, I will pay you for your trouble."
SKINNER's Defence. I was going to work.

ASKIN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

SKINNER -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1318.
JANE BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of June , 1 bed, value 2s.; 1 blanket, value 1s.; 2 sheets, value 2s.; 1 rug, value 1s. 6d.; 1 saucepan, value 6d.; 1 kettle, value 6d.; 1 poker, value 4d.; 2 pillows, value 9d., and 1 bolster, value 9d., the goods of
Francis Tadman
, in a lodging-room .
FRANCIS TADMAN. I live in Leonard-street. I let the prisoner a lodging a fortnight ago - I went for my rent, and found the door locked, and the room stripped - I had her apprehended.

WILLIAM EDWARDS
. I am an officer. I found the duplicate of a sheet on her - the pawnbroker is not here; the other property has not been found.
NOT GUILTY .

1319.
THOMAS BENTLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , 1 snuff-box, value 20s., the goods of
Radcliffe Pond
, from his person .

RADCLIFFE POND. I live at Chelsea. I was in Pallmall
on the 4th of June in the evening, and felt a trifling touch at my coat pocket; immediately after the prisoner endeavoured to rush by me; I caught him with my left hand, felt in my pocket, and missed my box, and found him putting it up his sleeve.(Property produced and sworn to.)

EDWARD BOOTHMAN
. I took him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw a boy drop it, and took it up; it was done to lead me into a snare.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1320.
EDWARD EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , 1 pistol, value 4s. , the goods of
Joseph Smith
.
JOSEPH SMITH. I am a gun-maker . On the 13th of April I gave my son a pistol to take to Somers'-town; he returned in about twenty minutes without it, crying.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am a constable. I received information, and went with the little boy, who pointed the prisoner out; I asked him where the pistol was; he denied it; I said I knew he had got it; he then said, "Say nothing about it, I will go, and give it to you;" he took me down Gray's-inn-lane, and gave it me from under several things; I have known him nine years; he behaved well; I believe he was in distress.
Prisoner's Defence. The boy held it up to several people; I thought he ought not to have such a thing, and took it from him.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined One Month .

1321.
FRANCIS WALKER
was indicted for
stealing on the 4th of June , 14 pieces of brass, value 18d., and 1 piece of copper, value 6d. , the goods of
Charles Handley
, his master.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer. On the 4th of June I went to the Britannia public-house, Portland-street, and saw the prisoner come out of the house of Mr. Charles Handley, his master, who was with me; I went and took off his hat, and found this brass in it; Mr. Handley claimed it in his presence; he said he was very sorry he had been guilty of it; his master gave him a good character; but is too ill to be here.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Confined Three Months .
Second London Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1322.
THOMAS THORP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of May , 1 whip, value 3s. , the goods of
Joseph Elcocks
.
JOSEPH ELCOCKS. I am a carman . On the 14th of May I was in Foster-lane, and while I was delivering some goods my whip was taken from the cart; I met the officer with it in half an hour.

JAMES GIBBENS
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner in Butcherhall-lane, with the whip in his hand.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

1323.
WILLIAM TURTLE
and
THOMAS MORLEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , at St. Pancras, Soper-lane, 3 table-cloths, value 2l. 8s., the goods of
Thomas Lewis
and
John Thomas James
, in their dwelling-house .

THOMAS LEWIS. I live in Queen-street, Cheapside, in the parish of St. Pancras, Soper-lane
, and am in partnership with John Thomas James - we are linen-drapers
. On the 10th of April these three table-cloths were on our front counter in the warehouse, which is part of our dwelling-house - they were missed about eleven o'clock that day, and are worth from 2l. 5s. to 2l. 8s; they were bleached, which make them worth 2l. 8s.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were they worth 2l. 8s. to sell again? A. No.

THOMAS HAYLOCK
. I am a constable of Middlesex. On the 10th of April I was at the end of Ironmonger-lane, and saw the prisoners with another person - I heard the other one say, "It is of no use standing here, we will go to work;" I followed them down Queen-street, and saw Turtle go into the prosecutors' house, No. 7, Queen-street, with nothing in his hand, and come out with these three table-cloths under his arm - I took him directly - the prosecutors claimed them. Morley did not go into the house - they were walking together - I cannot swear that they spoke together.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am on officer. I saw Haylock takeTurtle, and I took Morley; the other went away - I did not see Turtle go in or come out; as there was a disturbance in the street with the carts.
MR. LEWIS. These are our table-cloths, and have our mark on the paper.
Prisoner TURTLE. Morley knows nothing of it.

TURTLE -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 16.

MORLEY -
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1324.
GEORGE SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William Thompson
, from his person .

WILLIAM THOMPSON. I live in Gloucester-buildings, Walworth. On the 25th of May, at a quarter-past four o'clock, I was in Watling-street
, and thought I felt something at my pocket - I turned round, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand, concealing it under his jacket - I took it from him, and gave him in charge - I saw nobody with him.

JOHN JACKSON
. I am a constable, and received him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A lad gave it into my hand.
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Transported for Seven Years .

1325.
ABRAHAM ISAAC
,
DAVID MOSES
, and
SAMUEL BARNET
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of May , 1 pocket-book, value 1s., the goods of
Alfred Elken
, from his person .

The prosecutor's name being
Alfred Benjamin Elkin
, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED , but ordered to be detained till next Session.

1326.
GEORGE HARDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 trunk, value 10s.; 1 coat, value 30s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 10s.; 12 printed bound-books, value 10s.; 80 sheets of printed paper, value 10s., and 2 pocket-books, value 4s. , the goods of
George Leonard Swile
.

GEORGE LEONARD SWILE. I am a baker , and lodge in a second floor, in Water-lane, Fleet-street
. On the 28th of April my trunk, containing this property, was taken from my room - I left it safe at half-past two o'clock - a person was cleaning the room - I returned about twelve at night, and it was gone - I have found none of the things - I had not seen the prisoner there that day - he used to bring coals to my former lodging, in Crown-court, Whitefriars - it was a hair-trunk.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Had you left the servant to clean the room? A. She comes at times to do it.

SARAH SWILE
. I am the prosecutor's mother - we keep a little shop at this house. On the 8th of April, about five o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came to my room; he looked much confused - he came in at the side door, not at the shop door - he asked the price of a penny pie, then turned round, shoved the door too, and stood with his back to it - he went out at the side door, and seemed alarmed - I do not know whether he went up-stairs; he took a two-penny pie, and went away.
Cross-examined. Q. There was a way to the shop, through the side door? A. Yes, he had no coals with him; I never knew him bring coals to that house.

MARY MERCHANT
. I live in Water-lane. I have known the prisoner some time by sight. On the 28th of April, about five o'clock, I was standing at my street door, which is opposite to Swile's - I saw a very respectable man, dressed in blue, walking to and from by the door - the prisoner was inside the passage, and a hair trunk laid in the passage by him, near the door - the man in blue stepped up, took she trunk on his left shoulder, and walked down the lane as fast as he could; the prisoner came out in about two minutes, with two pies in his hand - he was by the trunk when the man took it. I did not say what I had seen till next morning - I had heard of the robbery at twelve o'clock at night; I did not see them speak to each other; it was done momentarily.

PHOEBE PULSFORD
. I live with this witness, and keep a school. I know the prisoner, and saw him go into Swile's passage that afternoon - I saw nothing more.

ALEXANDER JOHNSON
. I apprehended the prisoner - he denied the charge. I saw nothing more.
MRS. SWILE. I never knew him to bring coals to this house; I have been there six months; he said nothing to me about a trunk being in the passage.
NOT GUILTY .

1327.
WILLIAM TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of April , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

JOHN GIRTON
. I am a constable of Broad-street. On the 23d of April, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner and another in Cornhill
, as the mail coaches were starting - I saw the prisoner go behind a gentleman, and take a yellow handkerchief out of his pocket; I touched the gentleman on his back, and told him what I had seen - he turned to come across the street with me, but my eye was upon the prisoner, and I lost the gentleman; I followed the prisoner and his companion into the Old Jewry - they went down Princes-street, and were coming into Cheapside again; I took hold of the prisoner, and companion ran away; I took the prisoner up Meeting-house-court, and searched him - I found the handkerchief in his hat; he said it was his own - he had no other. I do not know the gentleman's name.
JURY. Q. Was he out of your sight? A. No.

Prisoner's Defence. I had bought the handkerchief on Monday, and gave 2s. 6d. for it - I put it into my hat, and was going down the Old Jewry; this man came and took me - the handkerchief has a blue stain on it; I got into conversation with the other lad, and he went to the pump.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Life .

1328.
JOSEPH GREEN
and
JAMES SMITH
were indicted
for breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Nightingale
, on the 30th of April (he and others being therein), and stealing 3 eye-glasses, value 15s. , his property.

GEORGE NIGHTINGALE. I live in Leadenhall-street
. and rent the house - I am a carver and gilder . On the 30th of April, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I was at home, and saw the prisoner very close at my window, drawing these eye-glasses out; my lad secured them on thespot - they had broken the window to get them out - it was secure before - they are worth 15s.; they threw them down on the pavement.
Prisoner GREEN. Q. Did you see me take them? A. I saw the fingers of somebody.

JOHN DAVIS
. I am in Mr. Nightingale's employ. I saw the prisoners at the window, alone; the glass was whole just before. I went out, and secured them both together. I did not see any thing taken - the window appeared to be cut; as soon as I took hold of them Green threw down two eye-glasses off the curb, and Smith threw one down an area; two knives, ground down for the purpose, were found on them at the watch-house.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am a constable, and received them in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GREEN'S Defence. I happened to look into the window - this man came out, and took us.
GREEN - GUILTY. Aged 14.
SMITH - GUILTY. Aged 13.

Of
stealing only . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1329.
WILLIAM ADAMS
was indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
Margaret Coram
, in the night of the 9th of May , and stealing 5 snuff-boxes, value 1l. 11s. , her property.

MARGARET CORAM. I am a widow , and live in Clothfair
; I rent the house - I deal in snuff-boxes and other things. About eight o'clock in the evening of the 9th of May, I was sitting in my shop, near the window, where the snuff-boxes were in a paper case - a pane of glass was cut, which was quite whole before this; I did not hear the cutting, but I saw the case drawn out about two inches; I saw two boys at the window, and could distinguish their features, as there was a great light from the gas; the prisoner was the biggest of the two. I went to the door, and took hold of the prisoner; the other ran away with the boxes; I should think it was light enough to see a person's features. I did not see more than the two boys.

THOMAS DAVIS
. I am in the employ of Mr. Smith, a woollen-draper, who lives nearly opposite Mrs. Coram's. - About half-past seven o'clock in the evening of the 9th of May, I was standing in the shop, and saw the prisoner and four more; I watched them till eight o'clock - there is a book shop nearly opposite, which they were looking into- about eight o'clock I saw them opposite Coram's - three of them went one way, and the prisoner and another went up to the shop; they stood there about five minutes - the prisoner had his back to the window, and the other was between him and the window; the other shoved his hand against the window, and then ran away; I could not see whether he took any thing; Mrs. Coram ran out, and asked who had broken the window; I said the prisoner was one of his companions.

JOHN RYLEY
. I am an officer. I took charge of the prisoner - he had nothing but a bit of wood.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming home through Clothfair; a little boy asked me which was Smithfield - I pointed it out to him, and was standing there when the lady came out, and said, "Did you see any body run away?" this man came out, and said I was one that cut the window - a lady came up, and said "Never mind - I will say you did not break it," and she gave me her direction, but I forget it.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Of
stealing only . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1330.
JOHN BOND
and
JOHN CLARKE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , one handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Watson
from his person .

JOHN WATSON. I am a linen-draper , and live on Holborn-hill. On the 28th of April, about nine o'clock in the evening I was between Brook-street, Holborn
and Gray's-inn-lane
; I was walking along, and as I frequently do, I put my hand slightly to my pocket, and found I had no handkerchief - I was not more than two hundred yards from home - I had it when I left home; the moment I missed it I turned round, and saw Clarke going away from me, about five yards from me - I pursued, and collared him. I found my handkerchief in the left breast of his jacket. I dragged him into a shop. I saw a little boy dressed like Bond near him, but a few yards from him - two officers followed me into the shop, and they brought in Bond.

WILLIAM PRITCHARD
. I am an officer. I saw the prosecutor in the street, about two hundred yards within the City. I had been watching the two prisoners for an hour. I saw Bond try Mr. Watson's pocket several times, without success, and just as he passed a tailor's shop by Brook-street, Bond took the handkerchief out of his pocket, and ran off directly - I pursued and took him, and found another handkerchief on him, which I had seen Clarke take from a gentleman half an hour before - they were together.
CLARKE's Defence. I picked up the handkerchief.

BOND -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

CLARK -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .

1331.
JOHN KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , one pair of stockings, value 10d. , the goods of
John Hamell
.

JOHN HAMELL. I am a hosier , and live in Aldersgate-street
. On the evening of the 30th of May, at a quarter past nine o'clock, I was serving a lady, and heard a report of a pull, which pulled these stockings down, they hung about two feet within the door, and were pinned with two strong pins. I turned my eye, that way and missed them. I made no noise, but pursued the prisoner, who I caught sight of about ten yards from the house, and stopped him forty yards off with the stockings rolled up in an apron, which was tied before him - there were two others in his company. I had see the prisoner before, and cautioned him to be careful.

WIYLIAM DORRINGTON
. I took him in charge with the stockings.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

1332.
WILLIAM BUTLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May , 1 quire of printing crown paper, value 1s. 6d., and 58 sheets of demy, value 3s. 4d. , the goods of
Thomas White
.

THOMAS WHITE. I am a printer , and live in Crane-court, Fleet-street
. I kept my paper in the cellar; the house door is generally open all day; the prisoner is a stranger. On the 4th of May, at half-past six o'clock in the afternoon, I heard a cry of thieves, ran down stairs, and found him in custody, in the yard, with this paper.

WILLIAM DON
. I am servant to Mr. White. I had occasion to go into the yard, and saw the prisoner in the privy - I asked what brought him there; he said he had occasion to go there; I was not satisfied, came out, and bolted the yard door - I called the other workmen; I saw him, through a broken pane of glass, unbutton his waistcoat, and throw some paper from it, into the dusthole; it was master's; he must have taken it from the cellar.

THOMAS LIGHTFOOT
. I am a constable, and took the prisoner in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went into the yard to the privy, as I was directed there - I never saw the paper.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Six Weeks .

1333.
WILLIAM MARSHALL
and
JOHN OULDS
were indicted for
embezzlement .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JOSHUA HEARN
. I am a coach and waggon proprietor, and keep the King's Arms Inn, Snow-hill ; when I receive parcels, I deliver them to the persons to whom they are directed - Marshall was clerk , in what we call the upoffice; he was to keep an account of the goods received by waggon, and to deliver them to the porters for delivery; he had to make out tickets, with the charge on the parcels to be delivered, and to keep an account of what was received for them. Oulds was my carman for the city; it was his duty to receive money for the parcels he delivered; he was his duty to receive money for the clerk named Jessopp; Oulds could not receive that money without the printed ticket delivered to him by Marshall; it was Marshall's duty to enter in a book marked B what parcels he received - I have a weigh-bill, which was made in the country, dated the 30th of March; the carriers make the weigh-bills, and Marshall keeps them.

STEPHEN JESSOPP
. I am in the employ of Mr. Hearn, and know Marshall's hand-writing; this ticket (looking at it) is his hand-writing. except the printed part of it - I have no doubt of it. (Read.)
"King's Arms, Snow-hill. 30th March. - 5 sacks, carriage 4s. To be delivered to Brooks and Co. J. Oulds, porter."

On the 30th of March Oulds did not account to me for any money received from Brooks; here is the book marked B., which Marshall kept; it is in his hand-writing; he has not entered 4s. as received by Oulds from Brooks.

ISAAC BUTCHER
. I am in the employ of Mr. Brooks, a merchant, of Sambrook-court; this bill was delivered to me on the 30th of March, by Oulds, to the best of my recollection; he often delivered goods; I paid him 4s. according to the ticket; to the best of my belief it was two shillings and a half-crown piece; he said he had no change; I told him he might take the man who had assisted him with the goods, and spend the 6d. over the way; he had delivered five sacks of potatoes and some bacon.

Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. Can you, with certainty, say you paid him two shillings and a half-crown? A. To the best of my belief it was - I recollect giving him the 6d. over - I had received parcels from him before, and am certain he brought these - I am sure I gave him one shilling.

GEORGE HAZLEWOOD WORRALL
. I am beadle of St. Sepulchre. I took Marshall into custody about a month ago - I neither threatened nor promised him any thing - I told him I took him for making bad entries in Mr. Hearn's book - he told me, at the top of Newgate-street, that he was drawn into this case by the two porters, Oulds and Satchell.
Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. What case? A. This case of felony - he said, "I was drawn into it by the two porters" - this was as he was going to Guildhall, to be examined on this charge.
COURT. Q. When he was first taken did he say any thing? A. He fell down on his knees to Mr. Hearn, who said, "I do not want any of that nonsense."
MR. ANDREWS to S. JESSOPP. Q. Do you keep the accounts of the office? A. I receive all monies from the porters - this would be entered in the book B.
